title: Navigating the Holidays With a Digestive Condition

content: Having a digestive condition such as IBS or IBD can be challenging year-round. But the holidays are particularly hard between travel, decadent food and cocktails, and both good and bad stress. Here’s some advice for navigating the season while still enjoying it:

This should obviously be a priority all year long, but you’ll want to pay special attention to it right now. The holidays tend to be prime time for stress, which is known to worsen many digestive conditions. Exercise, including walking, is a smart choice since it both reduces stress and helps keep your GI system moving. Try to let go of what most exhausts you about the holidays, whether that’s attending every function or sending holiday cards. And don’t be afraid to cancel or postpone something if you just don’t feel well.

You probably know some of the foods and drinks that trigger your symptoms. Many of the common culprits for people with digestive issues tend to be everywhere during the holidays, such as alcohol and high-fat dishes. Mocktails are trendy right now, so consider ordering an alcohol-free drink. If you feel pressured by a host to eat something you know is a problem food for you, ask to take some home instead (where you can either share or toss it).

sections.heading: Eat a Pre-Meal Snack
content: It’s common for people to overeat at big, delicious holiday meals, but that can aggravate your system. Eat a safe, nourishing snack beforehand so you’re not tempted to overdo it. Eating quickly can also trigger bloating, so set your fork down periodically during meals as a reminder to slow down and savor.

If you’re unsure about what’s being served at a party or dinner, offer to bring a dish to share that you know you can digest well. If you’re comfortable doing so, fill your host in so they know why you may not partake of everything they serve. They may even offer to modify the menu – most people are more than happy to make accommodations for loved ones. If you’re traveling, pack safe food in case you can’t find something that works or don’t have time to grab a bite between flights.

content: When you’re out and about, it’s smart to use the restroom whenever you have the chance. Even better, take a moment to plan for bathroom stops when you’re shopping all day or traveling through airports. If it’s helpful, look at maps online in advance to see where the restrooms are located.

It can be stressful to travel when you have a condition like Crohn's disease or IBS. Be sure to include items that will make you feel more comfortable wherever you are, such as deodorizing spray for the bathroom, safe nonperishable snacks, a travel pillow that will help you get better rest, or a favorite tea that brings you comfort. Assemble an emergency kit with items you’ll need if things go south. That might include OTC or prescription medicines for flare-up symptoms like diarrhea, a change of underwear, hand sanitizer, and cleansing wipes.
